Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: SHF: A Community Case Environment for Empowering Transformative Requirements Engineering Research

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Requirements Engineering (RE) is the part of the field of Software Engineering that is concerned with "getting the right system" (requirements satisfaction) as well as "getting the system right" (correctness). For Cyberphysical Systems (CPS), system requirements play a big role in specifying and achieving functionality, runtime adaptation, design-time evolution of requirements, environmental assumptions, safety assurance cases, and the like. In order to bring RE to CPS, the research community is in need of shared infrastructure and case studies to pursue its research agenda. The proposed project is to create a realistic environment for supporting research in software evolution, safety assurance of product-lines, runtime-adaptation, requirements modeling, safety-assurance, and related research. The environment will be called "Dronology" an Unmanned Autonomous Vehicle (UAV) system for supporting search and rescue. Significant effort will be invested in engaging a community of RE researchers so that Dronology meets their current and future research needs.

The work involves a combination of research, infrastructure development, and educational factors. It will deliver a fully-working system with an initial set of features to enable safe, coordinated flight of both virtual and physical UAVs in potentially populated areas. In addition, an extensive set of supporting artifacts will be developed that include requirements, domain descriptions, architecture documents, variability points, and safety assurance cases. Open research questions will be identified and analyzed, and then reflected in the composition of Dronology artifacts. The project will enable this community of users to also participate in contributing artifacts and code. The PI and several other members of the RE community plan to teach courses using Dronology and to cooperatively develop curriculum and share experiences. UAV/drones are an attractive, hands-on application area to engage students in RE.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The emerging adoption of Cyber-Physical Systems (CPS) in areas ranging across autonomous driving, smart cities, and unmanned aerial systems makes it imperative to address software engineering research challenges related to safety assurance in CPS.  Funding provided under this grant has enabled an initial phase of development for the Dronology system.  Dronology provides functionality for managing, monitoring, and coordinating the flights and coordinated missions of multiple small Unmanned Aerial Systems (sUAS) for use in emergency response scenarios including river rescue and defibrillator delivery.  As accidents, such as in-air collisions or uncontrolled landings into vehicles or pedestrians, have the potential for causing significant harm to people or property,  Dronology has been developed as a safety-critical system and therefore provides an environment for supporting research in diverse areas of safety-critical software engineering.

Researchers can use the Dronology system to explore topics such as runtime adaptation,  runtime monitoring, and  use of artificial intelligence in a safety-critical domain.

In addition to providing a runtime environment, the project has produced multiple versions of diverse software artifacts such as hazards, faults, environmental assumptions, requirements, design definitions, architectural design, a feature model, use cases, acceptance tests with test logs, unit tests, source code, and bug reports.  Researchers exploring topics such as requirements analysis, change impact analysis, modeling, and testing can utilize these artifacts. This set of artifacts is extensible and represents the fundamental elements of a safety-critical system. 

Currently many software engineering concepts do not progress past the early idea stage because researchers lack the means to advance them through intermediate exploratory stages.   The current lack of a publicly available CPS research environment is a significant impediment to research in the safety-critical CPS space and the ongoing Dronology project aims to fill this gap. Once completed, the Dronology system will enable researchers to experiment in a controlled environment and to advance their research  from inception to technology transfer.

The project is described at http://dronology.info and the entire environment is available upon request at https://github.com/SAREC-Lab/Dronology-Community-Documentation.

The Dronology project represents a team effort with over 30 contributors including undergraduate students, graduate students, post-doctoral researchers, professional software developers, and full-time academics.
